If you aren't from the US, seeing Tintin's name may be like meeting an old friend, but he's like soccer: in the United States, people just never have gotten Tintin, a beloved figure around the world since the 1920s, hero of a series of comic strips and books by Belgian artist HergÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â©, pen name of Georges Remi (1907ÃƒÂ¢Ã¢â€šÂ¬Ã¢â‚¬Å“1983). 

Tintin is a reporter, probably Belgian (but HergÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â© never made his nationality clear). He always (after all these decades) looks boyish, and part of the charm of the series is that a boy is cast into all kinds of serious situations; with innocence and honesty, he deals with a range of criminals and problems and comes out on top. We know nothing about his family; we do know that he lives alone, reads widely, apparently speaks several languages, and is in top physical condition. His fashion sense may leave something to be desired. Of course, he couldn't be so successful without his faithful sidekick, his fox terrier Snowy (Milou in French), whose thought balloons provide a running commentary on the stories. Slapstick comedy mixes with sophisticated satire, as well as political and cultural commentary throughout the stories, and the more you know about history, the more you will appreciate the Tintin stories. 

The books balance Tintin's rather bland personality with a variety of eccentric supporting characters, making some people think of the works of Charles Dickens (HergÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â© claimed to be influenced by Mark Twain) - from Captain Haddock, an alcoholic given to absurd but inoffensive oaths to the Thompson Twins (yep, that's where the musicians got their name), detectives who have as much trouble with the language as with the clues, on to Bianca Castafiore, who (some claim) was based on Maria Callas.

Tintin in the Congo, the second book in the series, continues to be controversial both for its protrayal of Africans and for the large number of animals killed. It's hard to try to justify racism, but frankly, it seems tame compared to some US animated cartoons of the time. For his fifth book (The Blue Lotus), HergÃƒÆ’Ã‚Â© collaborated with a Chinese student to avoid perpetuating European mis-perceptions of China. The Dalai Lama has recognized Tintin for making Westerners aware of Tibet in Tintin in Tibet.

Alcoholism, violence against animals, racism - parents, take note. But, everyone take note of the elegant drawing, the careful research either in creating fictitious countries or speculating about space travel. Enjoy these little glimpses into a world that is almost, but not quite, our own.
